The volume of the shared blood and viral load is related to the type of syringe as described in Zule et al. [ 21, 22]. If all shared syringes were rinsed once, the shared volume of blood retained in the dead space would be around 0.0063ml resulting in 63 copies of the virion. For a reference value of transmission probability P
ref = 0.008 Eq ( 2) produces an estimate of p
0 equal to 1.3*10 −4. If all syringes are rinsed twice, the volume of shared blood is 0.001ml (10 copies of virion) and p
0 equal to 8*10 −4. We thus consider the estimate of p
0 to be between 1.3*10 −4 and 8*10 −4.
